climbs.name: Silhouettes
climbs.fa: John Halley, Alicia Kramar, Viktor Kramar 1987

content.description: Follow a thin crack up to a bolt then traverse right to the second bolt and continue up past two more bolts to the top of the wall. Crux is below the first bolt.
content.protection: 4 bolts, bolted anchor on top of the wall. Small wires or micro nuts protect the thin crack below the first bolt.
content.location: First bolted route on the lower wall. This is the first slab on the left on the trail to Fourth of July wall.

content.description: Clip a high-ish 1st bolt then trend up and left along a ramp feature to a bulge. Pull over this on good holds and trend right to a thin crack feature which leads straight up to the 3 bolt anchor (no chains). Small stoppers protect the crack and a 3/4 - 1 in. cam can be used between the 1st and 2nd bolts. Crux was getting over the bulge but the pitch is sustained.
content.location: The left leaning ramp feature is the best way to locate this route. There is a bolt about 10 feet off the ground at the beginning of it and bolts can be seen above/to the right.

content.description: Small rib just of the trail below the Silhouttes slab.
content.location: First climb on the trail to 4th of July Buttress. Below the lower wall with Silhouette and Full Frontal Fun.

climbs.name: Full Frontal Fun
climbs.fa: Tarn Heath, Mike Heath, Gretchen Daiber 2006

content.description: Slab climb to the right of Silhouettes. Start below the big rock on the ledge, head up and right past two bolts to the ledge, then continue up the upper face past two more bolts to the top of the slab.
content.location: Second bolted route on the lower wall, right of Silhouettes. This is the first slab on the left on the trail to Fourth of July wall.

climbs.name: Facelift
climbs.fa: Doug Klewin, Dave Lenz, Viktor Kramar 1988

content.description:
The best route on the crag, and one of the best face climbs in Leavenworth.

Interesting variety of holds. Some are high friction granite, while some feel almost like sandstone.

You must try this pitch.
content.location: The tallest part of the crag. start by a pointy block that is about 1 foot tall. First bolt is kinda a reach.

content.description: Climb past an overhang protecting with trad gear. Eventually move right to the steep perfect face and clip a bolt. Follow good, but strangely spaced bolts up a very good section of climbing.
content.protection: A few cams to 2 inches plus quickdraws. Anchors on top.
content.location: The rightmost route on the wall.
